facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 21, 1961 of Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 32 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 21, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 32 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 2, 1963 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: December 2, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-Henry Gannon who was a registered holder of 2674 shares of Gannon Dunkerley Company

facts.text: Henry Gannon was registered holder of 2674 shares of Gannon Dunkerley Company, private limited with registered office in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Henry Gannon who was a registered holder of 2674 shares of Gannon Dunkerley Company--a private Limited Company with its registered office in Bombay-

facts.text: Henry Gannon died on May 13, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: -died on May 13, 1945, having made and published a will disposing of his extensive estate in the United Kingdom and in British India.

facts.text: Gannon made and published a will disposing of his estate in UK and British India.

anchor.surface_text: having made and published a will disposing of his extensive estate in the United Kingdom and in British India.

facts.text: National Bank of India Ltd. obtained probate of Gannon's will in the United Kingdom.

anchor.surface_text: The National Bank of India Ltd. obtained probate of Gannons will in the United Kingdom and appointed the respondent James Anderson its attorney

facts.text: National Bank appointed James Anderson as attorney to administer estate in British India.

anchor.surface_text: and appointed the respondent James Anderson its attorney to administer the estate in British India.

facts.text: Anderson obtained Letters of Administration in India on August 14, 1946 to the estate of Gannon in British India.

anchor.surface_text: Anderson applied for and obtained in India on August 14, 1946, Letters of Administration durante absentia to the estate of Gannon in British India.

facts.text: 450 shares specifically bequeathed to certain legatees and share certificates delivered to them.

anchor.surface_text: 450 out of the shares were specifically bequeathed by Gannon to certain legatees, and in the course of administration, share certificates with transfer forms duly executed were delivered to the legatees

facts.text: Agreement dated August 14, 1946 between executor, Company and Morarka to sell remaining 2224 shares to Morarka.

anchor.surface_text: By agreement dated August 14, 1946, between the executor to the estate, the Company and one Morarka, the executor agreed to sell the remaining 2224 shares

facts.text: Share certificates for 2224 shares handed over to Morarka on October 12, 1946 against payment at Rs. 140 per share.

anchor.surface_text: of the Company to Morarka and pursuant thereto the relevant share certificates with transfer deeds were handed over to Morarka on October 12, 1946, against payment of the price at the rate of Rs. 140 per share.

facts.text: Morarka failed to present transfer deeds and share certificates for registration; Gannon's name remained on register.

anchor.surface_text: Morarka, for some reason which is not clear from the record, failed to present the transfer deeds and the share certificates for registration at the office of the Company and the name of Gannon remained

facts.text: Income-tax Officer made order under s.23A on March 26, 1953 for assessment years 1946-47 and 1947-48 deeming dividends distributed on May 26, 1947 and December 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment of the Company for the assessment years 1946-47 and 1947-48 the Income-tax Officer, Bombay, made an order on March 26, 1953, under s. 23A of the Income-tax Act, 1922 as it then stood that certain undistributed parts

facts.text: Deemed dividends: Rs. 61,051 on May 26, 1947 and Rs. 3,73,099 on December 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: of the assessable income of the Company shall be deemed to have been distributed as dividends amongst the shareholders as at the dates, viz., May 26, 1947, and December 22, 1947, of the General Meetings of the Company. The net dividends so deemed

facts.text: ITO issued notice under s.34(1)(b) to James Anderson on March 28, 1953 for year ending March 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: to be distributed in respect of the shares were Rs. 61,051 and Rs. 3,73,099. The Income-tax Officer then issued on March 28, 1953, a notice under s. 34 (1) (b) of the Income- tax Act addressed to James Anderson, Administrator

facts.text: Anderson submitted return but did not include deemed dividends.

anchor.surface_text: In compliance with the requisition Anderson submitted a return, but did not include therein the dividend deemed to have been distributed under the order dated March 26, 1953.

facts.text: ITO assessed Anderson including deemed dividends under s.18(5).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer in his order of assessment included dividends deemed to be distributed and after processing the amount under s. 18 (5) included it in the total income of Anderson and levied tax thereon

facts.text: Anderson's appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: at the appropriate rate. Andersons appeals against the order of the Income-tax Officer to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, were unsuccessful.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to Bombay High Court under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of Anderson the following questions were referred by the Tribunal to the High Court of Bombay under s. 66 (1) of the Income-tax Act- 1/Whether in the facts and in the circumstances of the case

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered first question in negative and declined second.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and declined to answer the second question. With special leave, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay, has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay, has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Anderson did not get his name entered in the register of shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: The estate of Gannon to which the Letters of Administration relate, vested by virtue of s. 211 of the Indian Succession Act, in Anderson, but he did not take steps to get his name

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us Gannon died in May 1945, and the dividend in respect of which orders under s. 23A were passed was deemed to be distributed

issues.text: Whether in the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessment made on Mr. James Anderson, Administrator to the estate in India of Mr. Henry Gannon deceased is valid in law?

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessment made on Mr. James Anderson, Administrator to the estate in India of Mr. Henry Gannon  deceased  is valid in law?

issues.text: whether in the facts and in the circumstances of the case the dividends of Rs. 61,051 and Rs. 3,73,099 deemed to have been distributed on 26th May 1947 and 22nd December 1947 respectively under s. 23A of the Income-tax Act were assessable in the hands of the applicant?

anchor.surface_text: If the above question is answered in the affirmative  2   whether in the facts and in the circumstances of the case the dividends of Rs. 61,051 and Rs. 3,73,099 deemed to have been distributed on 26th May 1947 and 22nd December 1947 respectively under s. 23A of the Income-tax Act were assessable in the hands of the applicant?

issues.text: whether the Act contains machinery for assessing dividends deemed to have been distributed by virtue of an order under s. 23A in respect of the shares held by a shareholder, when before the date on which the fiction of distribution becomes effective-viz., the date of the relevant General Meeting of the Company -the registered shareholder has died and his representatives have not been substituted in the register of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question in this appeal is whether the Act companytains machinery for assessing dividends deemed to have been distributed by virtue of an order under s. 23A in respect of the shares held by a shareholder, when before the date on which the fiction of distribution becomes effective-viz., the date of the relevant General Meeting of the Company -the registered shareholder has died and his representatives have number been substituted in the register of the Company.

issues.text: whether the principle that shareholder in s. 23A means registered shareholder applies only when the shareholder is alive or also where legal representative is invested with rights without registration

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner submits that the principle of those cases applies only when the registered share-holder is alive and the beneficial ownership in the shares is vested as a result of some transaction inter vivos in a person in whose name the shares do number stand in the Companys register, but number where by the grant of representation to the estate of a registered shareholder who has died, the representative is invested, without his name being entered in the register, with the rights of the shareholder.

issues.text: whether s. 24B extends legal personality of deceased beyond the previous year of death for deemed dividends under s. 23A

anchor.surface_text: the general provision in s. 24B for enforcement of liability against the legal representative of a deceased person to pay tax which would have been payable if such person had number died, has a limited application.

arguments.claim: The principle that shareholder in s. 23A means registered shareholder applies only when the registered shareholder is alive and beneficial ownership vested inter vivos, not where legal representative invested with shareholder rights without registration

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner submits that the principle of those cases applies only when the registered share-holder is alive and the beneficial ownership in the shares is vested as a result of some transaction inter vivos in a person in whose name the shares do

arguments.court_reasoning: Legal representative does not automatically become shareholder; cannot vote or be director without registration; s.35 Companies Act implies no automatic rights; obligations like calls discharged as representative duty, not as shareholder

arguments.claim: Shareholder in s. 23A means shareholder registered in books of company; only such shareholder liable for deemed dividend tax

arguments.claim: s.24B provision for liability of legal representative has limited application; does not extend to deemed dividends post year of death

anchor.surface_text: and the general provision in s. 24B for enforcement of liability against the legal representative of a deceased person to pay tax which would have been payable if such person had not died, has a limited application.

arguments.claim: Post account year expiry, receipts taxable as deceased's income in hands of legal representatives; fictional deemed dividends under s.23A extend deceased's legal personality to year of deemed receipt

arguments.court_reasoning: First argument inconsistent with Amarchand Shroff; second imports alien concept; s.24B does not warrant different interpretations for actual vs fictional income; no general provision for post-death estate income

arguments.claim: Apart from s.24B, legal representatives represent deceased's estate for taxation; authorities competent to assess them on estate income received to prevent revenue loss

arguments.court_reasoning: No specific provision relied on; Legislature failed to provide procedure; courts cannot supply omissions; charge must follow Act provisions; no deeming of estate income as personal income of representative

arguments.claim: s.24B extends deceased's legal personality for entire previous year of death; income before/after death in that year assessable, but not subsequent years

arguments.claim: Assessment on James Anderson as administrator invalid in law

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessment made on Mr. James Anderson, Administrator to the estate in India of Mr. Henry Gannon deceased is valid in law?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 21, 1961 of the Bombay

arguments.court_reasoning: No machinery provisions in Act for such assessment post death without registration and beyond s.24B scope

arguments.claim: Deemed dividends under s.23A create fiction of distribution and receipt but require assessment order to charge tax; no charge by s.23A order alone

anchor.surface_text: The order made by the Income-tax Officer under s. 23A gives rise to a fictional income it merely creates a fiction about distribution and consequential receipt of dividend. The order by its own force however does not charge the income to tax it has to

arguments.claim: Definition of assessee applies only to living persons; no provision for assessing deceased's estate without machinery like s.24B

anchor.surface_text: definition of assessee in s. 2 (2 ) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 as it stood at the material date in terms only applied to a living person, the words being a person by whom income-tax is payable and not a person by whom or by whose estate

holdings.text: The expression 'shareholder' in s. 23A of the Income-tax Act, 1922, means a shareholder registered in the books of the company, and such shareholder alone is liable to be taxed in respect of the dividend deemed to be distributed.

anchor.surface_text: that the expression shareholder in s. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, means a shareholder registered in the books of the company, and such shareholder alone is liable to be taxed in respect of the dividend deemed to be distributed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedents in Shakuntala and Howrah Trading Company cases applying textual interpretation of 'shareholder'.

holdings.text: A legal representative of a deceased registered shareholder does not automatically become a shareholder entitled to rights or liable as such without entry in the register of members.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the death of a shareholder his executor or administrator may enforce the rights of the shareholder or incur liability in respect of the shares to the Company, depends upon the nature of the right and the obligation... This implies that the legal representative does not acquire in all cases the rights of a shareholder

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analyzes rights/obligations under Companies Act s.35 and articles; representative duties distinct from shareholder status; rejects petitioner's distinction attempt.

holdings.text: The order under s.23A creates a fiction of distribution and receipt of dividend but does not itself charge the income to tax; a separate assessment order is required.

anchor.surface_text: The order made by the Income-tax Officer under s. 23A gives rise to a fictional income it merely creates a fiction about distribution and consequential receipt of dividend. The order by its own force however does not charge the income to tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of s.23A; fiction limited, requires machinery provisions for charge and levy.

holdings.text: Section 24B extends the legal personality of the deceased only for the previous year of death; it does not authorize assessment of income received thereafter, including deemed dividends.

anchor.surface_text: by the incorporation of s. 24B the Legislature has extended the legal personality of a deceased person for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died, and therefore the income either received by him before his death

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Amarchand Shroff precedent; s.24B liability limited to year of death; rejects extension to fictional income.

holdings.text: There is no machinery in the Income-tax Act for assessing and levying tax on deemed dividends under s.23A in respect of shares where the registered shareholder died before the deemed distribution date and representatives were not registered.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question in this appeal is whether the Act contains machinery for assessing dividends deemed to have been distributed by virtue of an order under s. 23A in respect of the shares held by a shareholder, when before the date on which the fiction

holdings.reasoning_summary: No special provisions beyond limited s.24B; definition of assessee for living persons; courts cannot supply legislative omission; applies to facts where death in 1945, deemed dividend 1947.

holdings.text: The assessment made on James Anderson, Administrator to the estate of Henry Gannon, is invalid in law.

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessment made on Mr. James Anderson, Administrator to the estate in India of Mr. Henry Gannon deceased is valid in law? ... We therefore agree with the High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with Bombay HC (different reasons); no valid machinery or charge post-death without registration; s.24B inapplicable beyond death year.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Act contains no general provision for assessing income received by the estate of a deceased person after the previous year of death as the personal income of the legal representative.

anchor.surface_text: But if the Legislature has failed to set up the procedure to assess such income, the Courts cannot supply it. The expression assessee in s. 2 (2) ... The charge to income-tax has therefore to be in accordance with and subject to the provisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: no deeming provision; charge under s.3 subject to Act; rejects policy-based assessment without machinery.

precedents.cited_proposition: the expression shareholder in s. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, means a shareholder registered in the books of the company, and such shareholder alone is liable to be taxed in respect of the dividend deemed to be distributed

anchor.surface_text: Howrah Trading Company Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central Calcutta 2

precedents.cited_proposition: the expression shareholder in s. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, means a shareholder registered in the books of the company, and such shareholder alone is liable to be taxed in respect of the dividend deemed to be distributed

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. Ellis C. Reid I.L.R. 5 Bom. 312 5 I.T.C 100.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. Ellis C. Reid I.L.R. 5 Bom. 312 5 I.T.C 100.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. Ellis C. Reid
precedents.cited_proposition: the definition of assessee in s. 2(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 as it stood at the material date in terms only applied to a living person... in the absence of appropriate provisions for collecting tax from the estate of a deceased person in the Act, the claim of the Income-tax Officer to make an assessment under s. 23A must fail

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1 v. Amarchand Shroff 2 48 I.T.R. 59.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1 v. Amarchand Shroff 2 48 I.T.R. 59.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Amarchand Shroff
precedents.cited_proposition: by the incorporation of s. 24B the Legislature has extended the legal personality of a deceased person for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died, and therefore the income either received by him before his death or by his heirs and representatives after his death in that previous year becomes assessable to tax in the relevant assessment year, but not the income received in the year subsequent to the previous or account year

anchor.surface_text: We therefore agree with the High Court, though for somewhat different reasons.

outcome.relief_summary: Court agrees with High Court that the assessment made on James Anderson, Administrator to the estate of Henry Gannon, is invalid in law
